author: Terry Teachout
title: ‘My Fair Lady’ Grown Accustomed to Success
text:
New York
Of all the great Broadway musicals of the postwar era, “My Fair Lady” is the only one that takes a major work of literature, George Bernard Shaw’s “Pygmalion,” and turns it into an equally distinguished musical that is true to the spirit and letter of its source material. Not slavishly so—Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe put a romantic spin on Shaw’s deliberately unromantic satire of the British class system—but it’s remarkable how much of “My Fair Lady” either comes straight out of “Pygmalion” or is clearly...
